review.title: Data structuring for the ontological modelling of wind energy systems
review.abstract: Small wind projects encounter difficulties to be efficiently deployed, partly because wrong way data and information are managed. Ontologies can overcome the drawbacks of partially available, noisy, inconsistent, and heterogeneous data sources, by providing a semantic middleware between low level data and more general knowledge. In this paper, we engineer an ontology for the wind energy domain using description logic as technical instrumentation. We aim to integrate corpus of heterogeneous knowledge, both digital and human, in order to help the interested user to speed-up the initialization of a small-scale wind project. We exemplify one use case scenario of our ontology, that consists of automatically checking whether a planned wind project is compliant or not with the active regulations.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Small wind projects in the field of renewable energies encounter difficulties to be used efficiently, partly because data and information are mismanaged [12, 3]. Ontologies can overcome the disadvantages of partially available, loud, contradictory and heterogeneous data sources [15]. Domain-specific ontologies have already been developed for the renewable energy sector [14, 10, 13]. In this line, we aim to develop an ontology for the field of wind energy. Ontology was developed in the RacerPro (Renamed ABox and Concept Expression Reasoner Professional) knowledge presentation and argumentation system [9]. In our opinion, RacerPro and the associated Knowledge Representation System Specification (KRSS) syntax for Description Logic Axioms are powerful technical tools that support ontology engineering behind the basic capabilities provided by GUI-based ontology editors.

sections.heading: 2 Technical instrumentation
sections.text: The wind data is modeled in an ontology that is a semantic framework for the organization of information. We formalize wind data in Description Logic (DL). sections.heading: 3 Reusing related ontologies
sections.text: The process of ontology engineering began with: 1) the use cases of ontology, 2) the definition of a set of competence questions, and 3) the analysis of existing ontologies for possible repetition.First, the use cases of ontology include i) "assessing the feasibility of installing a specific small wind turbine in a specific location" or ii) verifying whether a small wind project is compatible with current regulations. Second, a solution to narrow the scope of an ontology is to define a list of competence questions (CQs) [16]. CQs are questions an ontology can answer to satisfy use cases, making CQs initial requirements and they can be used to validate ontology.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion and ongoing work
sections.text: Ontology can help wind farm operators reduce costs and comply with current wind energy regulations. Ontology will help wind farm operators make informed, evidence-based decisions about the construction and maintenance of a wind project. We have not focused here on the issue of reasoning for data streams [7] that are continuously captured by sensors. Ontology is currently being expanded to include terrain analysis, infrastructure, environment, and full regulatory constraints in a single predictive map that identifies the most appropriate location for wind energy research.
